Subject: Looking east from the future site of the Entry Gate, this shot shows where the zoo's large animal house was located.  This would eventually become the Flat Garden and the road would become the walkway around the garden.  To get the elevation correct, about 4 feet of of soil was removed leaving very little other than clay for soil.  Note Mt. Hood on the horizon.
Slide Mount Notation: JG start.  Old monkey house. Ground removed 4' deep for flat garden

Subject: The maple was planted in a large whole to accommodate the large root ball and the tree would not live long as the soil was so poor.  Eventually the large specimen transplants were set on top of the clay while mounding good soil aorund them.  The building was the zoo commissary and was turned into the public bathrooms for the garden.  Park supervisor (Ed Ericson?) had the roof removed to the ceiling joist to make a flat roof.  Robbie preferred the original look.
Slide Mount Notation: Planted Jan. '63. First Japanese maple from downtown freeway.  It died and was replaced with one from Sellwood
75 yr. old maple transplanted Jan. '63.  from Foothill Freeway from Korea

Subject: Dragline preparing to dig stroll garden.  The hillside in the background is where the Heavenly Falls will eventually be.  Professor Tono buried all the rocks that were there because they were jagged and not acceptable for use in the garden.  Robbie didn't know any of the people, but the man in the white rain coat appears to be Ed Erickson, architect for the city parks.
Stroll Garden excavation.  This area is where the bear pit was located and where the Lower Pond will be located.  Kingston St. is behind the chain link fence.

Stroll Garden excavation looking from above eventual Upper Pond site and down what will be the stream.  Note the deep ditch running along the eventual path of the stream.  The city, recognizing the danger of landslides, required this drainage system to catch any water that spills out of the ponds or stream.  It drains out across the road (Kingston?)
Drainage  below stroll garden stream.  Looking bach toward the hillside where the Azalea Hill will be located.

The round concrete pad (left center) for the Sapporo Pagoda has just been poured.  The metal motor hood/cover for the mixer stands in the foreground.
stroll garden concrete lining for the Upper Pond and the stream.

stroll garden concrete lining work done by Hoichi Kurisu.  Robbie says that Prof. Tono's legs were bothering him and he was unable to come back to Oregon by this time. Moving an acer palmatum from Clark residence in NW Portland near Cornell Road.  Planted along walk way above Upper Pond just above the willow.  This is the tree that has become known around Portland as "That Tree in the Japanese Garden."

maple in Flat Garden that died.  Note that the whole root ball had been placed in the soil rather than set on top for drainage.

Flat Garden inner path in 1965.  This was the only time a bark dust mulch was used.  Robbie was standing a few steps inside the path with his back to the eventual wisteria arbor looking toward the east.  The Olympic Lantern today stands just out of frame on the left.  Note the white trunk and red twigs of a birch tree in the upper right corner.  The pavilion would have been visible in the photo behind the birch.  Three birch trees were planted in the Flat Garden for their quick growth.  They were removed years later when other material got bigger.

Heavenly Falls concrete work above the bowl of the Lower Pond.    The stones on either side of the concrete work are left over from the zoo bear pit area.  Left of center is a concrete bear den structure.  According to Robbie, Prof. Tono wasn't sure what to do with them as they weren't proper for use in the garden.  He finally decided to bury them and they were later covered  on the hillside with soil for the plantings.

An overflow drainage/sewer line under the pond was to collect water from leaks or overflow.  The city required the pond edge be 2 feet higher than the intended water level.  Tono placed stones along edge of pond to help hide the exposed edge.

Koto Lantern and the stone footbridge across the Strolling Pond stream.  The large round stones came from Boone Canyon in Gilliam Co. near Lone Rock.  Professor Tono described the stones he wanted to use for stepping stones and Robbie knew where to find them.
stones were not mortared.  Often moved by kids sneaking into garden.

Subject: Flat Garden wooden pagoda.  Stolen after about a week.  Donated by a Japanese boatwork.
Flat Garden with Spirit Bridge in background

Entry gate construction. Tono designed it.  From JGSO President Thaddeus Bruno's Sept., 1966, progress report to the board of directors:  "The Entrance Building, a gift of the Autzen Foundation, being built by George A. Moore, contractor, (ed. note: Mr. Moore was a JGSO board member) is nearing completion.  This is a striking and interesting building with massive, carved beams of cedar and a delightful Oriental atmosphere.  The hand-made roof tile has been ordered from Nara, Japan for the Entrance Building, Tea House and parapet wall surrounding the Stone and Sand Garden.  Professor Tono has advised that the tile should arrive in January (1967.)  This is a very significant portion of the Japanese building design.  The individualtiles are large, over 12" square, hand-made, and each structure requires over twelve different tile shapes to provide authentic roof treatment."
Old gentleman hired to clean cobbles
Area adjacent to arbor on the hillside above the pagoda.  This area was referred to by Robbie as the Mountain Garden.  It was later removed by one of the gardeners.

The laceleaf maple currently (2008) in this location seems to have been moved the winter of 66-7 to replace the Mt. Fuji cherry originally planted there. (see J321 slide mount dated 4-67)
Divider placed in stream to narrow width and create more space for the iris.  Iris planted between stream and side walk.

Hokkaido stones came from Sandy River near Dodge Park.  Note lace leaf maple left of pagoda.  Probably moved to this location the winter of 66-7 to replace the Mt. Fuji cherry originally planted there. (see J321 slide mount dated 4-67)
flat garden.  Cherry tree training bamboo

New iris bed.   From JGSO President Thaddeus Bruno's Sept., 1966, progress report to the board of directors:  The Portland Garden Club by unanimous action of its Board of Directors has given the Japanese Garden Society the sum of $5,000 for the two Iris Gardens.  These lovely and dramatic iris beds are located on each side of the main water course and directly below the Shrine Waterfall.  These areas will have special rock and landscaped treatment.  The specimens and color varieities come from the Walter Marx Iris Gardens in Boring and the Cooley Gardens in Silverton.

Building moon bridge.  Robbie told this story:  the city engineers said we had to have a center support.  Tono said the city is going to spoil my bridge.  The center post disappeared the next winter and when Tono visited next he was pleased.

Building moon bridge.   From JGSO President Thaddeus Bruno's Sept., 1966, progress report to the board of directors:  "Mrs. Truman S. Collins has donated $5,000 for the Moon Bridge, a charming arched structure which will cross the water-course near the Tea House.  Footings for this structure are now being installed and actual building will be accomplished by Japanese carpenters to insure authenticity.  Professor Tono designed the bridge.

The Entry Gate nearly completed.  Longtime garden member and former president of the JGSO Maggie Drake told a story about visiting Japan with other Portland representatives and dignitaries.  During the visit a bus trip to Nara was arranged.  As the bus was traveling down the road, Mr. Bill de Weese jumped up and yell "Stop the bus!"  He got out and went to a tile making factory the bus was passing to make arrangements for aquiring tile for our garden.  Maggie remembers the factory owner was befuddled and did his best to make his unexpected guests feel welcome.
nearly complete entry gate.  Trough was filled with pebbles to catch water from roof.

Techtronix made a significant donation to bring an authentic Tea House to the Garden.  Professor Tono commissioned the construction of a tea house in Japan.  The structure was built, taken apart, packed with reassembly instructions and sent to Portland.  The States Steamship Company, owned by long-time garden supporters Jack and Mary Dant, donated transportation from Japan to Portland.  The crated, pre-fabricated Tea House, 1653 bags of Shirakawa Sand, and several other garden items arrived in November, 1967, or January, 1968 (conflicting information.)  Note Mr. Hira's dog, Hana, lying in the road.
Kinya Hira (left) & a local (unnamed in any sources to date) Japanese carpenter.
The Tea House arrived, unassembled, in boxes.  A huge plastic tent was erected so that the spring storms wouldn’t stop construction.  A local Japanese carpenter was hired to fit the pieces together.

Following the Iyo Stone dedication, the party moved to the Tea House for its dedication.  Tea Master Soi Yamada, head master of Sohen-ruiji School from Kamakura conducted a tea ceremony.  In this photo Kinya Hira, the first Japanese Landscape Director for the garden, is standing on the left wearing a gray cap with his back to the camera.

Following the Iyo Stone dedication, the party moved to the Tea House for its dedication.  Over 500 people were invited including Japanese dignitaries, local leaders, representatives of local Japanese and gardening associations, and all garden members.  Mr. R.W. "Bill" deWeese, board member, made remarks and a tea ceremony concluded the fesitivities.
Following the Iyo Stone dedication, the party moved to the Tea House for its dedication.

The Moss Garden.  Note the Sand & Stone Garden wall in the upper left and the chain link fence that parallels Kingston St.  This garden was laid out by Tono (very hastily according to Robbie) at the end of one of his visits upon requests by some to build a moss garden.
The Old Lantern in the Moss Garden

Prof. Tono's lacked any quality materials to work with for planning this garden.  He took the small stones on site and made a ring surrounding the 5-tiered pagoda and created some planting spaces along the path.  The path to the right slopes upward to the Sand & Stone Garden level.
Entry Gate window.   Fence on left is bamboo with Scotchbroom brush.
Ikebana arrangement in Entry Gate window.
Hoichi (John) Kurisu at top of path to Entry Gate.
Hoichi (John) Kurisu & Ruby Hiltenbrand the first executive secretary.
Fence in the Flat Garden where pavilion will eventually be.
Large stone from Japan now in Flat Garden sitting in crate.
Iyo Stone and smaller accompanying stone.  Both are from Japan.

Poetry Stone.  Japanese poet, Mizuhara Shuoshi wrote the haiku after visiting the garden in the 1960's.  One translation: "Here I saw the same soft spring as in Japan."  According to Robbie, this and the large irregularly shaped stone sitting near the west side pavilion steps arrived from Japan at the same time.

Iyo Stone to commemorate the first president of the Japanese Garden Society of Oregon, Mr. Phillip Engelhart, who died suddenly while traveling in Europe.  The stone comes from the Ehime (originally called Iyo) prefecture on the island of Shikoku.  Iyo stones are one of three "blue" stones that are most valued for thier use in Japanese gardening.  Chichibu (Saitama prefecture) and Kishu (Wakayama prefecture) are the other blue stones.  Here it is covered in snow.

Before leaving to return to Japan, Prof. Tono put these stone here and said he would do something about them when he returned.  The water basin stone was carved by a worker nearby with a jackhammer.  Prof. Tono said that we don't do it that way in Japan.
Upper Pond with Tea House
Slide Mount Notation: was bus poster    Rose City Transit

Subject: Faith Mackness in Moss Garden.  Lava rock was used because it was available.  Prof. Tono did not like that rock.
Old Lantern in the Moss Garden
Moon Bridge and upper pond with Tea Garden gate.
Moon Bridge.  Note varigated juniper left center.  Still there (2008) but it is slowly being shaded out.  Note Tam juniper near bridge corner post.  It was used to fill space and later removed.

This arrangement just below and south of the wisteria arbor was laid out by Prof. Tono and later removed by one of the gardeners so the stone could be used elsewhere.  Robbie said it was controversial and the gardener was in the dog house for a while….

The five-tiered pagoda of the old tomb-stone style was donated to the garden in 1965 by the Minobu Buddhist Temple, near Kofu.  It is sometimes called the Funeral or Tombstone Lantern.  Here is it seen in the Moss Garden.  When this garden was replaced, the pagoda was moved to the hillside above the upper Natural Garden pond.
Moss and fatsia at the base of the lantern.
Pine needle mulch covering the moss
Pine straw covering the moss.  Note little tents to protect plants in winter made of the horsetail grass
Pine straw covering the moss.  Note little tents to protect plants in winter made of the horsetail grass
Stones & Mugho pines at Entry Gate

Sand & Stone garden construction.  Out of sequence with neighboring slides.  Two series of numbers are stamped on the Ektachrome Film slide mount - "13-5153" and "11-02"     Could this be a photo of the conversion from the David Slausen designed garden back to Prof. Tono's original design?  Robbie has no photos of the Slausen design nor does he have any of the construction to the Slausen design and back to the original design in his entire collection for comparison
Slide Mount Notation: Out of sequence with neighboring slides.  Among other numbers stamped on mount is "11-02"     Could this design change to/from the Slausen garden?

Subject: Upper pond with Peace Garden and willow above it.  This was a second willow around the pond but was removed years later after it was crowded for light by the growing firs above it.
"Japanese Garden Society of Oregon" slide for traveling slide show.
Tea House.  Note there is no entry way in this photo.  The gate is out of picture to the left.
Tea House & upper pond.  Note park benches
Camellia tunnel.  These camellias came from Sellwood Park.  They were along the fence of the swimming pool and getting too big so they brought them here.

Robbie:  Boxwood specimem removed from vacant property across the street from St. Mary's Academy in downtown Portland.  The lot had been sold and the plants were auctioned off.  Andy Rocchia, garden writer for the Oregonian, bought the boxwood and donated it to the garden.  There was supposed to be a woman buried there and Boxwood were typically used as grave markers.  We were watching but never saw any bones.

Lower pond/snow viewing lantern.  The stone on which the lantern sits is came from the same Warm Springs Reservation quarry near Wapanitia Pass as the stones used in the Flat Garden Spirit Bridge.

Robbie:  The Moss Garden was abandoned because it was just a mudhole.  There was no drainage and it was always a muddy mess.
Truckloads of dirt dumped over Moss Garden which later became the Natural Garden.
Stones piled near Flat Garden covered in snow waiting for placement in the about to be created Natural Garden.
Stones piled near Flat Garden covered in snow waiting for placement in the about to be created Natural Garden.
City view and Rose Garden covered in snow.  Professor Tono said the tennis courts and rose garden reminded him of rice paddies.

Iyo stone and birch tree in snow. Robbie:  "Three of them planted by Professor Tono.  They make a show right away.  They're not the best plants for a Japanese Garden when the other plants grow up they can be removed.  And they were.  I hated to see them go when they got up there in height."
